Now all the truth is out,
Be secret and take defeat
From any brazen throat,
For how can you compete,
Being honor bred, with one
Who were it proved he lies
Were neither shamed in his own
Nor in his neighbors' eyes.
--W.B.Yeats

2017: Year 1 of the Trump Captivity of the GOP. Willful blindness and wishful thinking.
2018: Year 2 of the Trump Captivity: Mugged by reality.
2019: Year 3 of the Trump Captivity: The beginning of liberation .
2020: Year 4: The end of captivity. Trump defeated for renomination.

text: Very much enjoyed last night's high-spirited, quickly-thrown-together gathering w/ @weeklystandard colleagues past and present (well, past and recent). Now off to office to pack books. Have promised I'll get rid of many. (As a wise man once said, promises are made to be broken.)
author: BillKristol

text: All good things come to an end. And so, after 23 years, does The Weekly Standard. I want to express my gratitude to our readers and my admiration for my colleagues. We worked hard to put out a quality magazine, and we had a good time doing so. And we have much more to do. Onward!
author: BillKristol

text: "The poets capture our plight with unparalleled poignancy. But we who live in the prosaic world of politics and deeds can do more than lament. William Gladstone put it well: 'The resources of civilization against its enemies are not yet exhausted.'"
author: BillKristol

text: "It will take a lot of work to create a new birth of conservatism—if it even is still called conservatism—that will support American freedom and greatness."

text:

text: The pseudo-sophisticated defenders of Trump’s assaults on judges, scientists, and civil servants try to give his crude attacks a patina of respectability. But nihilism isn’t skepticism and being a know-nothing isn’t being unconventional, no matter what his defenders pretend.

text: Skepticism about the conclusions of judges, scientists bureaucrats and experts is warranted. Debate over their arguments is necessary. But that’s not what Trump and Trumpists are doing. They’re trying to undermine and discredit the people and institutions who stand in their way.

text:
When the Trump presidency crumbles before a primary challenge in 2020, I'll think back to these lines from King John:
"Your nobles will not hear you, but are gone
To offer service to your enemy,
And wild amazement hurries up and down
The little number of your doubtful friends."
author: BillKristol

text:
Home from King John at @FolgerLibrary. Its closing lines seem relevant to the U.S. too:
"This England never did, nor never shall,
Lie at the proud foot of a conqueror,
But when it first did help to wound itself.
...Nought shall make us rue,
If England to itself do rest but true."
author: BillKristol

text:
10. Freedom isn't our only goal. But it is our key political goal. And it is the goal of freedom not just for us but for all people everywhere, the goal of freedom with its noble simplicity and even quiet grandeur, that gives meaning and elevation to the American experiment. 
END
author: BillKristol

text: 9. The people of China deserve to be free. The people of Saudi Arabia deserve to be free. This means, ultimately, regime change. How to help different peoples achieve freedom is a complicated question. The conditions of freedom and the paths to freedom are challenging.
author: BillKristol

text: 8. ...to diverse circumstances. We can always recall "the palpable truth, that the mass of mankind has not been born with saddles on their backs, nor a favored few booted and spurred, ready to ride them legitimately, by the grace of God," or by the dictates of History or Science.
author: BillKristol

text: 7. Those choices will always depend on the weighing of particular circumstances. This will often be difficult and controversial. But having the goal in mind would, I think, clarify and elevate our view. It would be a north star to help guide our reactions...
author: BillKristol

text: 6. ...sometimes, in the way the world works, sudden. I do think a relatively open embrace of freedom as our goal, and a relatively candid debate over means, would serve the nation well. Such a debate will resolve very few of the particular choices facing us.
author: BillKristol

text: 5. ...for a long time (Saudi Arabia). But surely our ultimate goal, after preserving and securing our and freedom, is to be a force for freedom in the world. And this means changing un-free regimes to free ones, or freer ones. This means regime change, sometimes gradual,...
author: BillKristol

text: 4. We sometimes use political or economic pressure. We rarely use and should  rarely use military force. And of course we realize that in the real world prudence requires that we be allied with oppressive regimes, sometimes terrible regimes (the Soviet Union), and sometimes...
author: BillKristol

text: 3. Now it goes without saying there are practical limits to what we can and should do to make this happen. Much of what we do is simply to serve as an example. We use diplomacy, public and private, to persuade other nations to move toward freedom. We help civil society abroad.
author: BillKristol

text: 2. I'm glad to have stimulated some debate, and I hope some re-thinking. I'll put my position simply. The case for regime change shouldn't really be controversial. The U.S. at its best has always stood for the proposition that all people everywhere deserve to be free.
author: BillKristol

text:

Oh, Red is Red, and Blue is Blue, and never the twain shall meet,
Till Earth and Sky stand presently at God’s great Judgment Seat.

text:
Fun week at the White House: Kelly and Bolton in a screaming match today outside the Oval. McGahn leaves as WH Counsel mid-week, rather than stay through midterms. Fred Fleitz, longtime Bolton aide who came with him to WH, suddenly leaves as NSC COS after four months.
What’s up?
author: BillKristol

text: A very important--if very depressing--report on the war in Afghanistan from @thomasjoscelyn.

text: A wonderful essay by my cousin, Martha Himmelfarb, on her father, the remarkable thinker and writer Milton Himmelfarb (and a fun uncle), on the occasion of what would be his 100th birthday.

text: Trump hopes demagoguing the Honduran caravan will save the GOP in November. Can Democratic candidates stay focused on their issues (health care, etc) while being serious about border security and perhaps criticizing Trump for blustering about border security but not achieving it?

text: This poll makes clear that a really big Democratic wave depends on significantly expanding the midterm electorate among young, female and minority voters. This has been hard to do in past midterms; the survey suggests it may be happening this year.

If you're Biden, you've got to be awfully tempted to run.
If you're Bloomberg, you've got to be inclined not to.

text:
"Democracy is not some harlot in the street to be picked up by some man with a Tommy gun. Democracy is based on reason, a sense of fair play, and freedom and a respect for the rights of other people."
--Winston Churchill, on the Greek Communists in 1945.

text:

text: One interesting finding: Only 55% of Republicans (about 15% of the electorate) qualify as true Trump Republicans. There’s more room for non-Trumpy GOP messages and for a non-Trump GOP messenger than many realize. And there should be more room after Nov. 6.

text: Got to hotel last night, watched Cubs-Rockies from 8th to 12th inning, conked out...and Rockies promptly won in the 13th. Why does it always work this way? You stay awake, stay awake, finally decide you can't stay up all night--and the winning run scores in the very next inning.

text: Asked at “breakfast” in the lobby of the Hampton Inn in Austin why I seemed a little morose. Explained it was due to the tragic outcome of last night’s Harvard-Rhode Island football game. Much Texas-style guffawing ensued. Didn’t have the heart to explain I wasn’t kidding.

text: My fellow conservatives are inclined to view today’s hearing as another marker in our decline. To some degree that’s right. But look at the 1983 yearbook. Don’t you cringe? Isn’t our attitude towards—and the reality of—gender relations better now than then? All is not decline.

text: Just boarded four hour flight. Kind of hoping WiFi doesn’t work so I’m not even tempted to go online and follow the hearing, which I’m sure will be perceptively analyzed on this fine website even absent contributions from me.

text: I don’t claim insight into Never Trumpers’ general views of the Kavanaugh situation—except they don’t all agree. For myself, I hope against hope that today’s hearing, along with other inquiries, allow an impartial spectator to come to a reasonable judgment about the likely truth.

text: We should, I think, be respectful of police officers and appreciate the difficulty and importance of their jobs. Needless to say--except I guess we do need to say it in the era of Trump and Fox News--we should not "revere" them.

text: Sad news. Roger L. Beckett, director of the Ashbrook Center at Ashland University, has died, far too young. A fine man and a strong leader in the task of teaching young Americans about the virtues and challenges of self-government. It is an honor to have worked a bit at his side.
author: BillKristol

text: As a New Yorker who rooted against the Yankees and for the Mets and then picked up the Red Sox as my AL team when I got to Boston--how I wish I could have been there at Fenway today for this inspiring, uplifting, even transcendent moment!
author: BillKristol

text: Trump attacks Republican congressional leadership. Too much to hope that GOP leaders react by deciding to ignore Trump’s wishes and passing bipartisan legislation protecting Mueller, legalizing DACA recipients, and securing our elections?

text:
Former NH GOP chair Jennifer Horn:
"I think it's likely that Donald Trump will have a primary and that it is entirely his own doing. His behavior as president is damaging and demeaning to the presidency. I believe it has damaged our nation."
author: BillKristol

text:
204 years ago this morning, near Fort McHenry, Baltimore:
"Now it catches the gleam of the morning's first beam,
In full glory reflected now shines in the stream:
'Tis the star-spangled banner! Oh long may it wave
O'er the land of the free and the home of the brave!"
author: BillKristol

text:
A sobering must read from @JVLast.
"Then what?...Schism, the destruction of the papacy, and a long war for the soul of the Catholic church. Because the story of Theodore McCarrick isn’t just a story about sexual abuse. It’s about institutions and power."
author: BillKristol

text: It will be interesting to see how FL Gov and Senate candidate Rick Scott reacts to President Trump's Puerto Rico tweets.
author: BillKristol

text: I've always been struck that the first stanza of our national anthem ends not with a boast or a claim but with a question or a challenge: "Oh, say does that star spangled banner yet wave/O'er the land of the free and the home of the brave?" Self-government is an experiment.
author: BillKristol

text: 204 years ago this evening, on Sep. 13, 1814, at the "twilight's last gleaming" at Fort McHenry, Francis Scott Key proudly hailed the star spangled banner. It was famously still waving the next morning. It still waves--and the republic for which it stands still stands--today.
author: BillKristol

text: Not so sound sort of Marxist or anything, but when before in all of human history has a con man at the head of a gang of oligarchs been so shameless and so successful in presenting himself as a friend of the working man?

text:

text: As I wrote in 2004, on Sep. 11 we remember the attacks. But we also remember "the police & firefighters in New York, the servicemen & women in the Pentagon, and the passengers & crew of Flight 93. Sep. 11 was a day of infamy. But it was also a day of bravery, and of nobility."
author: BillKristol

text:
Dear The Greatest (as you suggested I call you),
Unlike your COS, I don't think you're an idiot. Unlike your SecDef, I don't think of you as a fifth grader. Unlike Anonymous, I don't admire McCain (my family never liked POWs either).
I'm your bro! So let's make a deal!
Rocket Man

#ImWithHer
author: BillKristol

text:

text: After reading a bit and watching some clips, I've got to say I'm sympathetic to Serena Williams. Why? NOT because I'm woke. Rather because I'm a traditional fan hostile to intrusive & snowflake-like umpiring, an American who roots for other Americans, & an admirer of excellence.

text: All according to plan. Anonymous gives Nikki a chance to “defend” the president while making clear she’s differed with and challenged him. So when Nikki runs against him in 2020, she can tell credulous Trump supporters she tried to support him and isn’t  a dishonorable turncoat.

text: Everyone cites individual Federalist papers, but who really explains, in an accessible way, the subtle and complex comprehensive argument of The Federalist as a whole? Harvey Mansfield, that's who. This conversation really is, I think, a must.

text:

text: On this day 74 years ago, George H.W. Bush, the youngest pilot in the U.S. Navy, was shot down near Chichi Jima. His two crewmen, radioman Jack Delaney and gunnery officer Ted White, did not survive. Bush made it to a life raft and was rescued. He later returned to the fight.
author: BillKristol

text:
"The America of John McCain is, yes, the America of Vietnam, fighting the fight, even in the most forlorn cause, even in the most grim circumstances...standing even in defeat for the life and liberty of other peoples in other lands."
 -- Meghan McCain, eulogizing John McCain
author: BillKristol

text:
"None of us will ever forget how even in his parting John has bestowed on us a much needed moment of unity and renewed faith in the possibilities of America. Henceforth, the country's honor is ours to sustain."
 -- Henry Kissinger, eulogizing John McCain, Sep. 1, 2018
author: BillKristol

text:
"It is the last great gift that John McCain gave America...we can give a last great gift to him, which is to nurture these values and take them forward into the years ahead to make America the better country John always knew it could be."
 -- Joe Lieberman, eulogizing John McCain
author: BillKristol

text:
"When John spoke of virtues like service and duty, it didn’t ring hollow....It was a truth that he had lived and for which he was prepared to die. And it forced even the most cynical to consider, what were we doing for our country?"
 -- Barack Obama, eulogizing John McCain
author: BillKristol

text:
"If we're ever tempted to forget who we are, grow weary of our cause, John's voice will always come as a whisper over our shoulder: We are better than this. America is better than this."
--George W. Bush, eulogizing John McCain, Sep. 1, 2018
author: BillKristol

text:
The tributes to John McCain at today's service (in addition to his daughter's) were given by a grandson of immigrants, first in his family to go to college; someone who fled Nazi Germany as a teenager; a president's son; and an African-American raised by a single mother.
America!
author: BillKristol

text: For me some of the most powerful moments of today's service were when we sang some of our great patriotic anthems. "Long may our land be bright, with freedom's holy light." "America! America! God mend thine ever flaw,/Confirm thy soul in self-control,/Thy liberty in law."
author: BillKristol

text: I don't believe the name of the current occupant of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue was mentioned during the service for John McCain,and I'll continue that practice, in McCain's honor, for the rest of the day. Today was a moment to celebrate, appreciate and reflect on what is admirable.
author: BillKristol

text: I suspect John McCain would have appreciated—both in the sense of enjoying but also viewing with a certain irony—the very Washington D.C. mixing and mingling going on here at the Cathedral before the ceremony begins.
author: BillKristol
